member.name: T:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Extensions.IEasyDAClientSettingsExtension
member.summary: Contains extension methods to the interface.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Extensions.IEasyDAClientSettingsExtension.TryEnableAutoSubscribingOptimization(OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.IEasyDAClientSettings)
member.summary: Attempts to enable the auto-subscribing optimization.
member.param: The client settings on which the operation will be performed.
member.returns: Returns true if the auto-subscribing optimization has been successfully enabled; returns false otherwise.

remarks.para: The auto-subscribing optimization can improve performance in scenarios with repeated Read requests, such as in certain Web applications or Web services.
The method succeeds in the default configuration of the OPC DA client object. It fails if the OPC DA optimizer plugin had been removed.

member.name: T:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Graphs.DANodeTreePosition
member.summary: A position in a tree of OPC DA nodes.

remarks.para: The node that corresponds to the root of the tree is special in that from the properties inherited from , only the Item Id is filled in.

The tree positions can be used to obtain information about the current node, and the nodes on the path to the root, but you cannot access child or sibling nodes of the current node. This is because the tree is constructed "on the fly", as the OPC address space is traversed, and sufficient information about child or sibling nodes may not be available.

overloads.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: Contains information gathered about a node in OPC server's address space.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

Initializes a new instance of the class, with the OPC server specified by machine name and server class, the OPC item specified by its ItemId and data type, the OPC group parameters specified by requested update rate and percent deadband, user-defined state object, and with a callback method.
member.param: Name of the machine. Determines the computer on which the OPC server is located. May be an empty string, in which case the OPC server is assumed to exist on the local computer or at the computer specified for it by DCOM configuration.
Contains ProgID of the OPC server.
Contains OPC item identifier.
Specifies the data type requested. Passing means that the server's canonical data type should be used.
How often should the updates be received (number of milliseconds).
The percent change in an item value that will cause an update.
A callback method to be invoked for each significant item change.
The state object (can be any value supplied by your code); available in event notifications.
member.remarks: If is a null reference, only the notification events are generated, but no callback method is invoked.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Optimization.DAAutoSubscribingParameters.AbandonIntervalMinimum
member.summary: Abandon interval minimum. Number of milliseconds. The OPC item is considered "abandoned" if no read requests to it have been made for abandon interval. In such case it is unsubscribed. The abandon interval is computed using the aggregated read rate and , but it is never shorter than value of this property.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than or equal to zero, or it must be equal to .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Optimization.DAAutoSubscribingParameters.AbandonRateMultiplier
member.summary: Abandon rate multiplier. Must be greater than or equal to 1.0. The OPC item is considered "abandoned" if no read requests to it have been made for abandon interval. In such case it is unsubscribed. The abandon interval is computed by multiplying the aggregated read rate and the value of this property, but it is never shorter than .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Optimization.DAAutoSubscribingParameters.AutoAdjustmentPeriod
member.summary: Auto adjustment period. Number of milliseconds. Specifies how often the engine automatically adjusts the parameters (such as update rate) of OPC items to match the observed usage pattern (e.g. the frequency of reading the item).

remarks.para: The value must be greater than zero, or it must be equal to .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Optimization.DAAutoSubscribingParameters.FastestAutomaticUpdateRate
member.summary: Fastest automatic update rate. Number of milliseconds. When the system automatically modifies the update rate of an OPC item, it never chooses a rate that is faster (has lower value) than the value of this property.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than zero.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Optimization.DAAutoSubscribingParameters.MaximumEffectiveValueAge
member.summary: The maximum effective value age in the Read request for it to be considered in auto-subscribing.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Optimization.DAAutoSubscribingParameters.MinimumEffectiveValueAge
member.summary: The minimum effective value age in the Read request for it to be considered in auto-subscribing.

remarks.para: Zero or low value ages have very little chances of cache hit with any subscription update rate.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Optimization.DAAutoSubscribingParameters.ReadIntervalAggregateMinimumValues
member.summary: The minimum count of data values in the read interval aggregate.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Optimization.DAAutoSubscribingParameters.ReadIntervalAggregateWindowSize
member.summary: The size of the window use by the read interval aggregate.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Optimization.DAAutoSubscribingParameters.RequestedUpdateRateFactor
member.summary: The factor used to calculate the requested update rate from the value age aggregate.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Optimization.DAAutoSubscribingParameters.SlowestAutomaticUpdateRate
member.summary: Slowest automatic update rate. Number of milliseconds. When the system automatically modifies the update rate of an OPC item, it never chooses a rate that is slower (has higher value) than the value of this property.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than zero.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Optimization.DAAutoSubscribingParameters.UpdateRateNegativeHysteresis
member.summary: Hysteresis for negative update rate changes. In percent, between 0.0 and 100.0. Requests to make the update rate of OPC item faster (i.e. lower value) will be ignored if the percentual change in update rate value is lower than the value of this property.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Optimization.DAAutoSubscribingParameters.UpdateRatePositiveHysteresis
member.summary: Hysteresis for positive update rate changes. In percent, between 0.0 and 100.0. Requests to make the update rate of OPC item slower (i.e. higher value) will be ignored if the percentual change in update rate value is lower than the value of this property.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Optimization.DAAutoSubscribingParameters.ValueAgeAggregateMinimumValues
member.summary: The minimum count of data values in the value age aggregate.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Optimization.DAAutoSubscribingParameters.ValueAgeAggregateWindowSize
member.summary: The size of the window use by the value age aggregate.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Optimization.DAParameterBucketingParameters.PercentDeadbandBucketsPerDecade
member.summary: Number of buckets per decade of percent deadband.
member.value: The percent deadband values (from 0.0 to 100.0) are divided into "buckets", using a logarithmic scale. This number specifies how many buckets will exist between values 10.0 - 100.0, and also 1.0 - 10.0, 0.1 - 1.0, and so forth. Percent deadbands requested will be adjusted so that the nearest bucket that fully satisfies the percent deadband requirement is used (i.e. the system may choose a percent deadband lower than requested, but not higher).

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Optimization.DAParameterBucketingParameters.UpdateRateBucketsPerDecade
member.summary: Number of buckets per decade of update rate.
member.value: The update rate values are divided into "buckets", using a logarithmic scale. This number specifies how many buckets will exist between values 100.0 - 1000.0, 10.0 - 100.0, 1.0 - 10.0, 0.1 - 1.0, and so forth, in both directions. Update rates requested will be adjusted so that the nearest bucket that fully satisfies the update rate requirement is used (i.e. the system may choose an update rate that is faster than requested, but not slower).

member.summary: Fastest update rate. Number of milliseconds. If your application specifies an update rate that is faster (has lower value) than the value of this property, the value of this property will be used instead.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than zero, or it must be equal to .

remarks.para: The value must be greater than or equal to zero, and less than or equal to 100.

member.summary: If your application specifies a percent deadband that is higher than the value of this property, the value of this property will be used instead.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than or equal to zero, and less than or equal to 100.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Optimization.DARequestChunkingParameters.ChangeItemSubscriptionsChunkSize
member.summary: Size of ChangeMultipleItemSubscriptions request chunks. 0 for no chunking.

remarks.para: The chunking is made regardless of the target server (endpoint). This means that when multiple servers (endpoints) are involved in the operation, the effective chunk size per server (endpoint) may be smaller than the value of this parameter.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Optimization.DARequestChunkingParameters.GroupByServer
member.summary: Determines whether the chunking will be performed for individual servers separately.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.Optimization.DARequestChunkingParameters.GetPropertyValuesChunkSize
member.summary: Size of GetMultiplePropertyValues request chunks. 0 for no chunking.

remarks.para: The chunking is made regardless of the target server (endpoint). This means that when multiple servers (endpoints) are involved in the operation, the effective chunk size per server (endpoint) may be smaller than the value of this parameter.

member.name: T:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DADataSource
member.summary: Selects the data source for OPC reads (from device, from OPC cache, or dynamically determined).

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DADataSource.ByValueAge
member.summary:
The data source (memory, OPC cache or OPC device) selection will be based on the desired value age and current status of data received from the server.
Remarks:
Value is 0.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DADataSource.Cache
member.summary:
OPC reads will be fulfilled from the cache in the OPC server.
Remarks:
Value is 1. Corresponds to OPC_DS_CACHE in the OPC specification.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DADataSource.Device
member.summary:
OPC reads will be fulfilled from the device by the OPC server.
Remarks:
Value is 2. Corresponds to OPC_DS_DEVICE in the OPC specification.

member.name: T:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DALimitChoice
member.summary: The Limit bit field of OPC quality.

remarks.para: The Limit Field is valid regardless of the QualityChoice and Substatus. In some cases such as Sensor Failure it can provide useful diagnostic information.
Server which do not support Limit return 0 (LimitOk).

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DALimitChoice.LimitOk
member.summary: Not Limited. The value is free to move up or down.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DALimitChoice.LimitLow
member.summary: Low Limited. The value has pegged at some lower limit.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DALimitChoice.LimitHigh
member.summary: High Limited. The value has pegged at some high limit.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DALimitChoice.LimitConst
member.summary: Constant. The value is a constant and cannot move.

member.name: T:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities
member.summary: Contains pre-defined constants of internal values.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.BadNonspecific
member.summary: Non-specific. The value is bad but no specific reason is known.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.UncertainNonspecific
member.summary: Non-specific. There is no specific reason why the value is uncertain.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.GoodNonspecific
member.summary: Non-specific. The value is good. There are no special conditions.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.ConfigError
member.summary: Configuration Error. There is some server specific problem with the configuration. For example the item in question has been deleted from the configuration.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.NotConnected
member.summary: Not Connected. The input is required to be logically connected to something but is not. This quality may reflect that no value is available at this time, for reasons like the value may have not been provided by the data source.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.DeviceFailure
member.summary: Device Failure. A device failure has been detected.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.SensorFailure
member.summary: Sensor Failure. A sensor failure had been detected (the Limits field can provide additional diagnostic information in some situations).

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.LastKnown
member.summary: Last Known Value. Communications have failed. However, the last known value is available. Remark: The age of the value may be determined from the TIMESTAMP in the OPCITEMSTATE.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.CommFailure
member.summary: Comm Failure. Communications have failed. There is no last known value is available.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.OutOfService
member.summary: Out of Service. The block is off scan or otherwise locked. This quality is also used when the active state of the item or the group containing the item is InActive.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.WaitingForInitialData
member.summary: Waiting for Initial Data. After Items are added to a group, it may take some time for the server to actually obtain values for these items. In such cases the client might perform a read (from cache), or establish a ConnectionPoint based subscription and/or execute a Refresh on such a subscription before the values are available. This substatus is only available from OPC DA 3.0 or newer servers.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.LastUsable
member.summary: Last Usable Value. Whatever was writing this value has stopped doing so. The returned value should be regarded as stale. Remark: This differs from a BAD value with Substatus 5 (Last Known Value). That status is associated specifically with a detectable communications error on a fetched value. This error is associated with the failure of some external source to put something into the value within an acceptable period of time. Remark: The age of the value can be determined from the TIMESTAMP in OPCITEMSTATE.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.SensorCal
member.summary: Sensor Not Accurate. Either the value has pegged at one of the sensor limits (in which case the limit field should be set to 1 or 2) or the sensor is otherwise known to be out of calibration via some form of internal diagnostics (in which case the limit field should be 0).

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.EguExceeded
member.summary: Engineering Units Exceeded. The returned value is outside the limits defined for this parameter. Remark: In this case (per the Fieldbus Specification) the Limits field indicates which limit has been exceeded but does NOT necessarily imply that the value cannot move farther out of range.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.Subnormal
member.summary: Sub-Normal. The value is derived from multiple sources and has less than the required number of Good sources.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualities.LocalOverride
member.summary: Local Override. The value has been Overridden. Typically this is means the input has been disconnected and a manually entered value has been forced.

member.name: T:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualityChoice
member.summary: The QualityChoice bit field, i.e. the most significant part of the OPC quality flags.

remarks.para: The OPC specification uses the name "Quality" for this bit field, which makes it possible to confuse with the full OPC quality value. We have made up the name "QualityChoice" in order to reduce the chances for confusion.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualityChoice.Bad
member.summary:
Bad. Value is not useful for reasons indicated by the Substatus.
Remarks:
Corresponds to OPC_QUALITY_BAD in the OPC specification.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualityChoice.Uncertain
member.summary:
Uncertain. The quality of the value is uncertain for reasons indicated by the Substatus.
Remarks:
Corresponds to OPC_QUALITY_UNCERTAIN in the OPC specification.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAQualityChoice.Good
member.summary:
Good. The Quality of the value is Good.
Remarks:
Corresponds to OPC_QUALITY_GOOD in the OPC specification.

member.name: T:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice
member.summary: Status is a combination of QualityChoice and Substatus. Which Substatus values can be used depend on QualityChoice.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.BadNonspecific
member.summary:
Non-specific. Substatus for BAD Quality: The value is bad but no specific reason is known.
Remarks:
Corresponds to OPC_QUALITY_BAD in the OPC specification.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.UncertainNonspecific
member.summary:
Non-specific. Substatus for UNCERTAIN Quality: There is no specific reason why the value is uncertain.
Remarks:
Corresponds to OPC_QUALITY_UNCERTAIN in the OPC specification.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.GoodNonspecific
member.summary:
Non-specific. Substatus for GOOD Quality: The value is good. There are no special conditions.
Remarks:
Corresponds to OPC_QUALITY_GOOD in the OPC specification.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.ConfigError
member.summary:
Configuration Error. Substatus for BAD Quality: There is some server specific problem with the configuration. For example the item in question has been deleted from the configuration.
Remarks:
Corresponds to OPC_QUALITY_CONFIG_ERROR in the OPC specification.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.NotConnected
member.summary:
Not Connected. Substatus for BAD Quality: The input is required to be logically connected to something but is not. This quality may reflect that no value is available at this time, for reasons like the value may have not been provided by the data source.
Remarks:
Corresponds to OPC_QUALITY_NOT_CONNECTED in the OPC specification.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.DeviceFailure
member.summary:
Device Failure. Substatus for BAD Quality: A device failure has been detected.
Remarks:
Corresponds to OPC_QUALITY_DEVICE_FAILURE in the OPC specification.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.SensorFailure
member.summary:
Sensor Failure. Substatus for BAD Quality: A sensor failure had been detected (the Limits field can provide additional diagnostic information in some situations).
Remarks:
Corresponds to OPC_QUALITY_SENSOR_FAILURE in the OPC specification.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.LastKnown
member.summary:
Last Known Value. Substatus for BAD Quality: Communications have failed. However, the last known value is available. Remark: The age of the value may be determined from the TIMESTAMP in the OPCITEMSTATE.
Remarks:
Corresponds to OPC_QUALITY_LAST_KNOWN in the OPC specification.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.CommFailure
member.summary:
Comm Failure. Substatus for BAD Quality: Communications have failed. There is no last known value is available.
Remarks:
Corresponds to OPC_QUALITY_COMM_FAILURE in the OPC specification.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.OutOfService
member.summary:
Out of Service. Substatus for BAD Quality: The block is off scan or otherwise locked. This quality is also used when the active state of the item or the group containing the item is InActive.
Remarks:
Corresponds to OPC_QUALITY_OUT_OF_SERVICE in the OPC specification.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.WaitingForInitialData
member.summary:
Waiting for Initial Data. Substatus for BAD Quality: After Items are added to a group, it may take some time for the server to actually obtain values for these items. In such cases the client might perform a read (from cache), or establish a ConnectionPoint based subscription and/or execute a Refresh on such a subscription before the values are available. This substatus is only available from OPC DA 3.0 or newer servers.
Remarks:
Corresponds to OPC_QUALITY_WAITING_FOR_INITIAL_DATA in the OPC specification.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.LastUsable
member.summary:
Last Usable Value. Substatus for UNCERTAIN Quality: Whatever was writing this value has stopped doing so. The returned value should be regarded as stale. Remark: This differs from a BAD value with Substatus 5 (Last Known Value). That status is associated specifically with a detectable communications error on a fetched value. This error is associated with the failure of some external source to put something into the value within an acceptable period of time. Remark: The age of the value can be determined from the TIMESTAMP in OPCITEMSTATE.
Remarks:
Corresponds to OPC_QUALITY_LAST_USABLE in the OPC specification.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.SensorCal
member.summary:
Sensor Not Accurate. Substatus for UNCERTAIN Quality: Either the value has pegged at one of the sensor limits (in which case the limit field should be set to 1 or 2) or the sensor is otherwise known to be out of calibration via some form of internal diagnostics (in which case the limit field should be 0).
Remarks:
Corresponds to OPC_QUALITY_SENSOR_CAL in the OPC specification.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.EguExceeded
member.summary:
Engineering Units Exceeded. Substatus for UNCERTAIN Quality: The returned value is outside the limits defined for this parameter. Remark: In this case (per the Fieldbus Specification) the Limits field indicates which limit has been exceeded but does NOT necessarily imply that the value cannot move farther out of range.
Remarks:
Corresponds to OPC_QUALITY_EGU_EXCEEDED in the OPC specification.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.Subnormal
member.summary:
Sub-Normal. Substatus for UNCERTAIN Quality: The value is derived from multiple sources and has less than the required number of Good sources.
Remarks:
Corresponds to OPC_QUALITY_SUB_NORMAL in the OPC specification.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAStatusChoice.LocalOverride
member.summary:
Local Override. Substatus for GOOD Quality: The value has been Overridden. Typically this is means the input has been disconnected and a manually entered value has been forced.
Remarks:
Corresponds to OPC_QUALITY_LOCAL_OVERRIDE in the OPC specification.

member.name: T:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.IEasyDAClientExtension
member.summary: Contains extension methods to the interface.

remarks.para: NOTE: This class is intentionally *not* placed in the Extensions namespace, but rather alongside the extendee. The extension methods in this class are commonly used, and from the point of view of the developer, can be considered as part of the interface. In addition, this placement allows less namespaces references in typical projects, and better consistency with the COM interfaces (as only methods from this extension class may appear in the COM interfaces).
Other extension classes may exist as well.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.IEasyDAClientExtension.ReadItem(OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.IEasyDAClient,OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.OperationModel.DAItemArguments,OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAReadParameters)

overloads.summary: Reads a named item from an OPC server. Value, quality and timestamp are returned.

remarks.para: The server can be local or can be remotely accessed via DCOM. Optionally, an access path can be specified or a specific data type can be requested.
The ReadItem method only waits for the first update from the server (or until the timeout elapses); it does not wait until the quality becomes "uncertain" or "good".

member.summary: Reads a named item using an item arguments objects, and read parameters.
member.param: The client object that will perform the operation.
Holds an OPC server and item descriptor.
The read parameters (such as data source or value age).
member.returns: If successful, the function returns a object. The object contains the value, timestamp and quality of the OPC item requested.

exception.para: A null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) is passed to a method that does not accept it as a valid argument.
This is a usage error, i.e. it will never occur (the exception will not be thrown) in a correctly written program. Your code should not catch this exception.

The OPC "Classic" (or OPC XML-DA) operation has failed. This operation exception in uniformly used to allow common handling of various kinds of errors. The always contains information about the actual error cause.
This is an operation error that depends on factors external to your program, and thus cannot be always avoided. Your code must handle it appropriately.

The ReadItem method only waits for the first update from the server (or until the timeout elapses); it does not wait until the quality becomes "uncertain" or "good".

remarks.para: The server can be local or can be remotely accessed via DCOM. Optionally, an access path can be specified or a specific data type can be requested.
The ReadItem method only waits for the first update from the server (or until the timeout elapses); it does not wait until the quality becomes "uncertain" or "good".

member.summary: Reads a named item using individual parameters specifying its location, and a specific data type.
member.param: The client object that will perform the operation.

Name of the machine. Determines the computer on which the OPC server is located. May be an empty string, in which case the OPC server is assumed to exist on the local computer or at the computer specified for it by DCOM configuration.
Contains ProgID of the OPC server to read from.
Contains OPC item identifier.
Specifies the data type requested. Passing will cause the value be returned in server's canonical data type.
member.returns: If successful, the function returns a object. The object contains the value, timestamp and quality of the OPC item requested.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.IEasyDAClientExtension.ReadItemValue(OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.IEasyDAClient,OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.OperationModel.DAItemArguments,OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAReadParameters)

overloads.summary: Reads a named item from an OPC server. Only the item value is returned (quality and timestamp are not returned).

remarks.para: The server can be local or can be remotely accessed via DCOM. Optionally, an access path can be specified or a specific data type can be requested.

Use this method if you are only interested in the actual value of the OPC item. Use ReadItem method if you also need the quality or timestamp. The ReadItemValue method makes it very easy to obtain the actual data value with just one function call.
The ReadItemValue method waits until the quality becomes "good", or the timeout elapses.

member.summary: Reads a named item from an OPC server. Only the item value is returned (quality and timestamp are not returned).

remarks.para: The server can be local or can be remotely accessed via DCOM. Optionally, an access path can be specified or a specific data type can be requested.

Use this method if you are only interested in the actual value of the OPC item. Use ReadItem method if you also need the quality or timestamp. The ReadItemValue method makes it very easy to obtain the actual data value with just one function call.
The ReadItemValue method waits until the quality becomes "good", or the timeout elapses.

member.summary: Reads a value of named item using individual parameters specifying its location, using server's canonical data type.
member.param: The client object that will perform the operation.

Name of the machine. Determines the computer on which the OPC server is located. May be an empty string, in which case the OPC server is assumed to exist on the local computer or at the computer specified for it by DCOM configuration.
Contains ProgID of the OPC server to read from.
Contains OPC item identifier.
member.returns: If successful, the function returns the actual value of OPC item requested.

exception.para: A null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) is passed to a method that does not accept it as a valid argument.
This is a usage error, i.e. it will never occur (the exception will not be thrown) in a correctly written program. Your code should not catch this exception.

The OPC "Classic" (or OPC XML-DA) operation has failed. This operation exception in uniformly used to allow common handling of various kinds of errors. The always contains information about the actual error cause.
This is an operation error that depends on factors external to your program, and thus cannot be always avoided. Your code must handle it appropriately.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.IEasyDAClientExtension.ReadMultipleItems(OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.IEasyDAClient,OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.OperationModel.DAItemArguments[],OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.DAReadParameters)
member.overloads: Reads named items from an OPC server or OPC servers. Values, qualities and timestamps are returned.

remarks.para: The servers can be local or can be remotely accessed via DCOM. Optionally, an access path can be specified or a specific data type can be requested.

The ReadMultipleItems method only waits for the first update from the server (or until the timeout elapses) for each item; it does not wait until the quality becomes "uncertain" or "good". The function performs all individual operations in parallel, but only returns after all individual operations are completed (or their timeouts elapse).
This method does not throw an exception in case of OPC operation failures. Instead, the eventual exception related to each item is returned in Exception property of each returned element.

member.summary: Reads multiple named items from a single OPC server, using item arguments objects, and common read parameters.
member.param: The client object that will perform the operation.
Array of item arguments objects (determine the OPC server and an OPC-DA item).
The read parameters (such as data source or value age).
member.returns: The function returns an array of objects. The indices of elements in the output array are the same as those in the input array, .
member.remarks: The size of the input array will become the size of the output array. The element positions (indices) in the output array are the same as in the input array.

exception.para: A null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) is passed to a method that does not accept it as a valid argument.
This is a usage error, i.e. it will never occur (the exception will not be thrown) in a correctly written program. Your code should not catch this exception.

overloads.summary: Reads named items from an OPC server or OPC servers. Only the item values are returned (qualities and timestamps are not returned).

remarks.para: The servers can be local or can be remotely accessed via DCOM. Optionally, an access path can be specified or a specific data type can be requested.

The ReadMultipleItemValues method requires that the quality is "good" for each item. The function performs all individual operations in parallel, but only returns after all individual operations are completed (or their timeouts elapse).
This method does not throw an exception in case of OPC operation failures. Instead, the eventual exception related to each item is returned in Exception property of each returned element.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.IEasyDAClient.ReadMultipleItems(OpcLabs.EasyOpc.DataAccess.OperationModel.DAReadItemArguments[])
member.summary: Reads multiple named items from an OPC server or OPC servers, using array of argument objects as an input. Values, qualities and timestamps are returned.
member.param: Array of arguments, one element per each OPC item involved in the operation.
member.returns: The function returns an array of objects. The indices of elements in the output array are the same as those in the input array, .

remarks.para: The servers can be local or can be remotely accessed via DCOM. Optionally, an access path can be specified or a specific data type can be requested.

The ReadMultipleItems method only waits for the first update from the server (or until the timeout elapses) for each item; it does not wait until the quality becomes "uncertain" or "good". The function performs all individual operations in parallel, but only returns after all individual operations are completed (or their timeouts elapse).
This method does not throw an exception in case of OPC operation failures. Instead, the eventual exception related to each item is returned in Exception property of each returned element.
The size of the input array will become the size of the output array. The element positions (indices) in the output array are the same as in the input array.

exception.para: A null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) is passed to a method that does not accept it as a valid argument.
This is a usage error, i.e. it will never occur (the exception will not be thrown) in a correctly written program. Your code should not catch this exception.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.Engine.EasyClientParameters.ClientReconnectDelay
member.summary: Client reconnect delay. Number of milliseconds. If operations on specific OPC server are found to be failing, the server is disconnected, and further connection is retried only after the client reconnect delay elapses.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than or equal to zero.

This property is used by following client implementations:
Native client: yes
NET API client: yes

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.Engine.EasyClientParameters.ComInstantiationParameters
member.summary: Contains parameters that influence instantiation of OPC servers.

remarks.para: There are separate parameters for instantiation of OPCEnum, in .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.Engine.EasyClientParameters.ServerFailedReconnectDelay
member.summary: Server failed reconnect delay. Number of milliseconds. If the OPC server indicates that vendor specific fatal error has occurred within the server, the server is disconnected, and further connection is retried only after this delay elapses.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than or equal to zero.

This property is used by following client implementations:
Native client: yes
NET API client: yes

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.Engine.EasyClientParameters.ServerShutdownReconnectDelay
member.summary: Server shutdown reconnect delay. Number of milliseconds. If the OPC server indicates that it needs to shutdown, the server is disconnected, and further connection is retried only after this delay elapses.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than or equal to zero.

This property is used by following client implementations:
Native client: yes
NET API client: yes

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.Engine.EasyClientParameters.ServerStatusCheckPeriod
member.summary: Server status check period. Number of milliseconds. Determines how often the system periodically checks the status of the OPC server (by calling IOPCServer::GetStatus method).

remarks.para: The value must be greater than zero, or it must be equal to .
This parameters has effect in both OPC Classic and OPC XML-DA.

This property is used by following client implementations:
Native client: yes
NET API client: yes

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.Engine.EasyEngineParameters.GarbageCollectionPeriod
member.summary: Garbage collection period. Number of milliseconds. Specifies how often the engine reviews the connected OPC servers and items and disconnects from those that are no longer needed.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than zero, or it must be equal to .

This property is used by following client implementations:
Native client: yes
NET API client: no

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.Engine.EasyEngineParameters.WorkerSleepDelay
member.summary: Worker sleep delay. Number of milliseconds. Specifies how often the engine checks the need to perform tasks such garbage collection, rate adjustment, and final cleanup.

remarks.para: The value must be greater than zero.

This property is used by following client implementations:
Native client: yes
NET API client: no

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.Engine.EasyEngineParameters.DefaultEventQueueSize
member.summary: Default event queue size. The maximum size of the queue each client object uses to temporarily hold generated events before they are consumed by the application. Events that do not fit into the queue will be lost. You should set the size to a number that is sufficient to cope with the difference between the rate events are generated and the rate your application is able to consume them.

remarks.para:
This property is used by following client implementations:
Native client: yes
NET API client: no

member.summary: Name of the machine. Determines the computer on which the OPC server is located. May be an empty string, in which case the OPC server is assumed to exist on the local computer or at the computer specified for it by DCOM configuration.
member.remarks: Machine resources are named using the naming scheme of the network transport. By default, all UNC ("\\server" or "server") and DNS names ("domain.com", "example.microsoft.com", or "135.5.33.19") names are allowed.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.NodeDescriptor.NodePath
member.summary: Contains node path (empty string for the root, null reference if unknown). Only used with OPC XML.

remarks.para: Not to be confused with the , or the access path (only in OPC-DA 1.0, and quite rare).
This is called ItemPath in the OPC XML-DA Specification. "OPC XML-DA addresses OPC Items via ItemPath, and ItemName."

ItemPath: "A portion of the namespace pointing to the data. The ItemPath is server specific and the client should not make any implications about its content, structure, or consistency across servers. ItemPath may or may not imply node, or server.
If an XML-DA server was front ending a DA based server, then an example could be: \\NODE\OPC.DAServer.2.
ItemPath is a hierarchical parameter. >br/> If ItemPath is Blank or missing at all levels of the hierarchy, then the ItemName is expected to be a fully qualified name."
This method or property does not throw any exceptions, aside from execution exceptions such as or .

member.name: M:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.NodeDescriptor.Match(OpcLabs.EasyOpc.NodeDescriptor)
member.summary: Determines whether the node descriptor matches another node descriptor.
member.param: The node descriptor to match against.
member.returns: Returns true if two node descriptors match; otherwise, returns false.
member.remarks: Two node descriptors match if any information that is present in both node descriptors is equal. For example, if a node Id in one of the node descriptors is not present (null), a node Id in the other node descriptor can be anything, or also not present. But if a node Id is present in both node descriptors, it must be the same node Id. Same rules apply to the browse path portion of the node descriptor.

exception.para: A null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) is passed to a method that does not accept it as a valid argument.
This is a usage error, i.e. it will never occur (the exception will not be thrown) in a correctly written program. Your code should not catch this exception.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerElement.Clsid
member.summary: Gets or sets OPC server's class identifier (CLSID).

remarks.para: A CLSID is a globally unique identifier that identifies an OPC server. The OPC server needs to register its CLSID with the system.
In VBScript, use instead.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerElement.ClsidString
member.summary: Contains the CLSID string of the server.

remarks.para: The value is an empty string if no CLSID for the server is given.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerElement.Description
member.summary: Gets or sets a user readable name for the OPC server.
member.remarks: The description may be presented to the user as the name of an available OPC server.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerElement.Location
member.summary: The server's location.
member.remarks: Corresponds to the host or machine name.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerElement.ProgId
member.summary: Gets or sets a string value indicating the programmatic identifier (ProgID) of the OPC server.
member.remarks: ProgIDs present a human-readable version of the class identifier (CLSID) used to identify COM/ActiveX objects.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerElement.ServerCategories
member.summary: Gets or sets information about which specifications the OPC server claims to support.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerElement.ServerClass
member.summary: Returns a string usable for identification of the OPC server when passed to other methods. If the is not empty, it is used. Otherwise, if the is not empty, it is used. If both are empty, the string form of server's is returned.
member.remarks: For consistency, the corresponding property or parameter on other objects and methods is also called ServerClass.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerElement.Technology
member.summary: Determines the OPC technology used.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerElement.Url
member.summary: A URL of the server.

remarks.para: This property is null if the underlying string does not represent a valid URI.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerElement.UrlString
member.summary: A URL string of the server.

remarks.para: A generic string is used instead of , because in some cases, the value may not represent a real URI.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerElement.UrlStringUnescaped
member.summary: An unescaped URL string of the server.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerElement.Vendor
member.summary: Gets or sets a vendor name.
member.remarks: Vendor name may be empty when unknown, e.g. if obtained through OPCEnum object which does not provide it. It is simply a means of identifying the vendor who supplied the particular OPC server.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.EasyOpc.ServerElement.VersionIndependentProgId
member.summary: Gets or sets version-independent programmatic identifier of the OPC server application.

remarks.para: VersionIndependentProgId may be empty when unknown, e.g. if obtained through IOPCServerList interface of OPCEnum object which does not provide it, or when registry does not contain that information. In some cases (e.g. when IOPCServerList2 is used, and the VersionIndependentProgID is not available in the registry), the ProgID will be copied to this property.
The VersionIndependentProgID associates a ProgID with a CLSID.

The version-independent ProgID refers to the OPC server's class and does not change from version to version, instead remaining constant across all versions. It refers to the currently installed version of the OPC server's class. The version-independent ProgID corresponds to the name of the latest version of the OPC server application.

member.summary: Converts the object into a string usable for identification of the OPC server when passed to other methods. The value returned is the value of the property.
member.returns: Returns the object contents expressed as readable string.

The OPC "Classic" (or OPC XML-DA) operation has failed. This operation exception in uniformly used to allow common handling of various kinds of errors. The always contains information about the actual error cause.
This is an operation error that depends on factors external to your program, and thus cannot be always avoided. Your code must handle it appropriately.
